channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Challenges China’s Claim of Islands With Maritime Operation
item.description: In an exercise intended to challenge excessive territorial claims by China, a United States vessel entered the disputed waters in the Paracel Islands without giving China notice.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Turkey Accuses Russia of Again Violating Its Airspace
item.description: Turkey’s Foreign Ministry said a Russian fighter jet entered the country’s airspace after radar units warned it to turn back.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Memo From Beijing: President Xi Jinping of China Is All Business in Middle East Visit
item.description: President Xi’s arrival after the lifting of sanctions related to Iran’s nuclear program provided a moment for China to set the stage for future deal-making.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China with King Salman of Saudi Arabia on a visit to Riyadh on Jan. 19.

item.title: Authorities Arrest Son of Ex-Leader in Sri Lanka
item.description: Yoshitha Rajapaksa, the second son of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa, was arrested by financial crimes investigators after being questioned over his involvement in alleged money-laundering.
item.dc:creator: DHARISHA BASTIANS and GEETA ANAND

item.title: Greece Resists Its Role as European Union’s Gatekeeper
item.description: Europe has reached a turning point in the migrant crisis, and is starting to coalesce around proposals that would effectively turn Greece into a giant processing center.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants at a Greek gas station as they waited for buses to the Macedonian border. The journey may become more difficult under new European plans.

item.title: Colombia Reports More Than 2,100 Pregnant Women Have Zika Virus
item.description: More than a third of pregnant women with the mosquito-borne illness are in a single province, the nation’s health institute said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: 10 Children Among the Dead as a Migrant Boat Capsizes Off Turkey
item.description: Coast guard officials said at least 33 people had died, and 75 were rescued. But officials suspect more migrants were trapped inside the boat and that the death toll will rise.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Bodies were found on the Turkish coastline after a migrant vessel capsized. Officials said at least 33 people had died and 75 were rescued.

item.title: Unemployed, Myanmar’s Elephants Grow Antsy, and Heavier
item.description: Elephants, which hold a near-mystical place in Myanmar, are out of work because of shrinking forests, and the nation must now figure out how to handle 5,500 pachyderms in captivity.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Thay Lay washed his elephant Hsar Hlay, 38, who is without work, after a foraging one night this month in the jungle near Wa Kalu Pu.

item.title: Indian Women Seeking Jobs Confront Taboos and Threats
item.description: The Indian Constitution guarantees equality under the law. But for women facing a patriarchal social order, strict caste rules and centuries of traditions, that guarantee means little.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Geeta led a group of women in her village in northern India to defy tradition and take jobs outside the home.

item.title: Miners in China Are Rescued After 36 Days Underground
item.description: The four men were among 29 miners caught when a cavernous gypsum mine in Pingyi County, Shandong Province, collapsed on Dec. 25. Thirteen are still missing.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A worker being lifted from the mine in Shandong Province, in eastern China, where he and others were trapped for 36 days. Thirteen miners were still unaccounted for.

item.title: At Some Restaurants in China, a Shortcut to Addictive Food: Poppies
item.description: At least 36 restaurants across China were investigated in the past week for adding poppy capsules and other illegal ingredients to food, the state news media said.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A branch of the Hu Da hot pot restaurant chain in Beijing. Hu Da is one of at least 36 restaurants across China that have been investigated for illegally using poppy capsules as seasoning.

item.title: Daughter-in-Law of Chile’s President Faces Corruption Charge
item.description: Prosecutors investigating a land deal said Natalia Compagnon, President Michelle Bachelet’s daughter-in-law, was part of a scheme to avoid paying taxes.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.media:description: Natalia Compagnon, right, the daughter-in-law of President Michelle Bachelet of Chile, in court in Rancagua on Friday.

item.title: British Woman Is Convicted of Joining ISIS
item.description: The authorities said Tareena Shakil, who went with her young son to Syria to become a “jihadi bride” but returned to Britain, was the first British woman convicted of joining the militants.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Taxing Google and Other U.S. Giants Is Dividing Europe
item.description: European Union officials in Brussels want uniform rules, but many countries prefer to use tax policies to reward or punish big multinationals.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: The European Union’s competition commissioner, Margrethe Vestager, second from left, spoke with the E.U.’s commissioner for economic and financial affairs, Pierre Moscovici, during a meeting in Brussels on Wednesday.

item.title: Tears and Bewilderment in Brazilian City Facing Zika Crisis
item.description: The Zika epidemic has spread much faster than science’s understanding of it.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Micaela de Souza took her 3-month-old daughter with microcephaly to see a doctor for a test result in Recife, Brazil, on Friday.

item.title: Vaccine for Zika Virus May Be Years Away, Disease Experts Warn
item.description: Not only are scientists still learning about Zika, but any vaccine must go through rigorous testing before it’s available to the public.
item.category: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.dc:creator: KATIE THOMAS

item.title: France Plans Mideast Peace Effort, and Recognition of Palestine if It Fails
item.description: The announcement was criticized by Israeli officials who said it would encourage the Palestinians not to negotiate seriously.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Syria Talks Are Complicated by Competing Opposition Groups
item.description: The difficult dynamic among competing groups in Syria was apparent even as the opposition refused to participate in the talks Friday.
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK

item.title: Swiss Question Use of Malaysian Sovereign Fund Run by Prime Minister
item.description: The sovereign wealth fund, called 1Malaysia Development Berhad, or 1MDB, has been the focus of investigations around the world involving misappropriated money.
item.dc:creator: LOUISE STORY

item.title: No Terror Link Found in Gun Arrest at Disneyland Paris
item.description: The man arrested Thursday with two guns at a hotel in the amusement park has no known links to terrorism but was still being held, the French authorities said.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
